Award.AwardTitle: Intermediates in the Reactions of Pterin-Dependent Hydroxylases
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Paul Fitzpatrick of the University of Texas Health Science Center-San Antonio to study the mechanism by which oxygen is activated when food is metabolized and converted into new cells and tissues. Molecular oxygen from the air consists of two oxygen atoms bonded together. Living organisms are capable of the incorporation of these atoms in biomolecules, a process that is not spontaneous and that requires the activation of the molecular oxygen. To achieve this goal, they use enzymes that contain metal ions. Dr. Fitzpatrick will study an iron-containing enzyme and pursue the elucidation of intermediates formed upon the chemical interaction between oxygen, the iron-containing enzyme, and the enzyme substrates. The work is having a broad impact on our understanding of the basic chemistry by which oxygen powers living organisms, as well as on the training of the next generation of scientists, including undergraduates who might not otherwise have the opportunity to become involved in scientific research.

The goal of the experiments being carried out in this project is to determine previously uncharacterized steps in the activation of oxygen by non-heme pterin-dependent enzymes. A variety of spectroscopic methods are being used to determine the structure of the NO complex of tyrosine hydroxylase with tyrosine and a tetrahydropterin bound as a model for the quaternary complex with oxygen. Rapid-reaction methods are also being used to trap and characterize an intermediate in the reaction of tryptophan hydroxylase and to address the role of proton transfer in cleavage of the oxygen-oxygen bond.

Institution.Name: University of Texas Health Science Center San Antonio
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER OF SAN ANTONIO

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Texas Health Science Center San Antonio

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fundamental questions in understanding how enzymes work are the role of protein structure in catalysis and how protein motions are coupled to catalysis. These questions have been addressed in studies of the aromatic amino acid hydroxylases using a combination of approaches. These enzymes form a highly reactive iron-oxygen species that reacts with the amino acid substrate. The formation of this intermediate must be prevented until the correct amino acid substrate is bound to the enzyme. With tyrosine hydroxylase, we have shown determined the structure of a mimic of the first intermediate after oxygen binds, a key step in developing mimics of the reaction and using computational approaches to elucidate details in catalysis. This identifies the key changes in the iron ligands necessary for the reaction with oxygen. With tryptophan hydroxylase, we have shown the binding of both substrates is coupled to closure of a surface over the active site; this movement is coupled to rearrangements of the active site required for the reaction with oxygen. With a bacterial phenylalanine hydroxylase, we have developed methods for determining the rate constant for formation of intermediates that will complement planned studies of the timing of protein motion. The combined results contribute to the growing evidence that local protein motions can be coupled to steps in catalysis.

This research has also contributed to the development of methodologies that will have application to the studies of other enzymes, including the use of NO as an oxygen mimic, the use of solvent viscosity to probe protein dynamics, and the use of global analyses of kinetic experiments to determine mechanism. Finally, the research has been important in training the next generation of biochemists, supporting a postdoctoral fellow and an undergraduate.


Last Modified: 11/02/2018
Modified by: Paul Fitzpatrick

These questions have been addressed in studies of the aromatic amino acid hydroxylases using a combination of approaches. These enzymes form a highly reactive iron-oxygen species that reacts with the amino acid substrate. This identifies the key changes in the iron ligands necessary for the reaction with oxygen. With a bacterial phenylalanine hydroxylase, we have developed methods for determining the rate constant for formation of intermediates that will complement planned studies of the timing of protein motion. The combined results contribute to the growing evidence that local protein motions can be coupled to steps in catalysis. This research has also contributed to the development of methodologies that will have application to the studies of other enzymes, including the use of NO as an oxygen mimic, the use of solvent viscosity to probe protein dynamics, and the use of global analyses of kinetic experiments to determine mechanism. Finally, the research has been important in training the next generation of biochemists, supporting a postdoctoral fellow and an undergraduate.
